articles.headline: New Disc May Sway DVD Wars
articles.snippet: Warner Brothers plans to announce a single videodisc that can play films and television programs in both Blu-ray and HD-DVD, the rival DVD technologies.
articles.abstract: Warner Brothers plans to announce a single videodisc that can play films and television programs in both Blu-ray and HD-DVD, the rival DVD technologies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Consumers wary of buying new high-definition DVD players because of a technology war reminiscent of the days of Betamax versus VHS will soon have a new kind of DVD that might make the decision less daunting.

articles.headline: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
articles.snippet: The departure of Home Depot’s chief was a victory for shareholders hoping to force corporate directors to be more accountable for executive pay.
articles.abstract: The departure of Home Depot’s chief was a victory for shareholders hoping to force corporate directors to be more accountable for executive pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: Arrogance has never been attractive in a leader. Now, in corporate chief executives anyhow, it may be a career ender.

articles.headline: Home Depot Ousts Highly Paid Chief
articles.snippet: The board decided that Robert L. Nardelli should go — with a $210 million exit package.
articles.abstract: The board decided that Robert L. Nardelli should go — with a $210 million exit package.
articles.lead_paragraph: In May, in a nearly empty basement ballroom at the Hotel du Pont in Wilmington, Del., Robert L. Nardelli, the chairman and chief executive of Home Depot, stood between huge timers, intended to limit questions from the handful of shareholders present. After dismissing questions about his compensation or the independence of the board, Mr. Nardelli abruptly ended the meeting after only 30 minutes.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Fewer Excuses for Not Doing a PC Backup
articles.snippet: Online backups, where files are shuttled off to the Internet for safekeeping, are suddenly becoming effortless, capacious and even free.
articles.abstract: Online backups, where files are shuttled off to the Internet for safekeeping, are suddenly becoming effortless, capacious and even free.
articles.lead_paragraph: If there’s one New Year’s resolution even more likely to fail than “I vow to lose weight,” it’s “I vow to start backing up my computer.”

articles.headline: Auto Sales at Big 3 Fall Further
articles.snippet: G.M., Ford and Chrysler ended 2006 with a new low in their collective market share — just 51.5 percent for December.
articles.abstract: G.M., Ford and Chrysler ended 2006 with a new low in their collective market share — just 51.5 percent for December.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Jan. 3 — The Detroit auto show, which opens next week, is all about new concepts, building buzz and making fresh starts. And the Detroit auto companies can use all of that.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: G.E. Magic Can Fade, After G.E.
articles.snippet: General Electric has long been seen as a training ground for future C.E.O.’s. The ouster of Robert L. Nardelli, a G.E. alumnus, may change that perception.
articles.abstract: General Electric has long been seen as a training ground for future C.E.O.’s. The ouster of Robert L. Nardelli, a G.E. alumnus, may change that perception.
articles.lead_paragraph: When boards of directors go shopping for a new chief executive, their first stop is often General Electric.

articles.headline: Mother Wonders if Psychosis Drug Helped Kill Son
articles.snippet: Eli Lilly found that patients taking Zyprexa would be more likely to develop heart disease.
articles.abstract: Eli Lilly found that patients taking Zyprexa would be more likely to develop heart disease.
articles.lead_paragraph: At first, the psychiatric drug Zyprexa may have saved John Eric Kauffman’s life, rescuing him from his hallucinations and other symptoms of acute psychosis.
